properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An Arctic air mass combined with strong northwesterly winds will give wind chill values near -38 from Sunday evening to Monday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-15T00:54:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-14T08:55:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0508475171.2021
Area: Chibougamau, Gouin Reservoir area, Parent area, Ashuapmushuan Wildlife Reserve area, Normandin - Péribonka area, Alma - Desbiens area, Saint-Félicien - Roberval area, Lake Bouchette area, La Tuque area, Manic-5 area, Manic-3 area, Chutes-des-Passes - Pipmuacan Reservoir area, Labrieville area, Falardeau - Mont-Valin area, Sainte-Rose-du-Nord area, Ville de Saguenay area, Rivière-Éternité - Petit-Saguenay area, Tadoussac - Baie-Sainte-Catherine area, Apica Mountain area, Grands-Jardins Park area, l'Étape area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Brief, intense snowfall is expected to develop. Under the snow squall, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for brief but intense bursts of heavy snow producing near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-14T14:59:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-14T07:29:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0649104749.2021

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions are expected Sunday night into Monday morning. Increasing winds and falling snow will lead to poor visibility in snow and blowing snow beginning early Sunday evening. Snowfall up to 5 cm and east winds gusting to 70 km/h may reduce the visibility as low as 400 m in blowing snow. Conditions will improve Monday as the snow tapers off and the winds begin to ease. This watch may be upgraded to a blizzard warning as the event draws nearer. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-14T12:11:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-13T20:12:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4096165979.2021
Area: Kugluktuk
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A few hours of heavy wet snow expected. A cold front will move across the central coast tonight. Heavy rain ahead of the front will quickly switch over to a period of heavy wet snow. Snowfall accumulations of 5 to 10 cm will likely occur in a short period of time with higher amounts expected over higher terrain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-14T18:54:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-14T08:36:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1602174172.2021
Area: North Vancouver Island, Central Coast - inland sections, North Coast - inland including Kitimat
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Periods of heavy snow are expected this afternoon. With the snow squalls, visibilities will be greatly reduced under the intense snow. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for brief but intense bursts of heavy snow producing near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-15T00:52:46-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm will begin tonight. Snow, at times heavy, will begin in areas north of Great Slave Lake, including areas near the north arm, this evening. Up to 10 cm of snow will fall tonight with an additional 10 to 15 cm expected by the time snow tapers off Monday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-14T14:49:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-13T22:50:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3767579283.2021

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. As a low pressure system intensifies over northern Baffin Bay, northwesterly winds gusting to 60 km/h will create blowing snow that will reduce visibilities at times later today. Winds are expected to intensify, gusting up to 70 km/h this evening. These winds combined with light snow are expected to create blizzard conditions with low visibilities in blowing snow. Blizzard conditions are expected to last until Monday night. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-14T22:08:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-14T06:09:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2042340996.2021
Area: Clyde River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Strong winds gusting as high as 80 km/h, combined with 4 to 8 cm of snow, will produce blizzard conditions starting this evening. The blizzard conditions will improve Monday morning as the winds begin to ease. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-15T00:27:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-14T08:28:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3591773274.2021
Area: Kugluktuk

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Additional snowfall: 5 to 10 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 80 km/h. Locations: Rigolet to Black Tickle. Time span: ending Sunday morning. Remarks: Fresh snowfall will combine with strengthening northwesterly winds to produce poor visibility in blowing snow tonight. Conditions will improve Sunday morning as the snow tapers to a few flurries. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-14T16:59:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-14T02:25:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2895727969.2021

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR QUESNEL The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with the Northern Health Authority has issued a Dust Advisory for Quesnel because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation, dust suppression or a change in traffic patterns. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Exposure is particularly a concern for individuals with chronic conditions such as asthma, COPD, heart disease, and diabetes, respiratory infections such as COVID-19, pregnant women, infants, and older adults. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Where appropriate, maintain physical distancing. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Staying indoors helps to reduce particulate matter exposure. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-03-15T01:26:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2021-03-14T09:27:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3836974957.2021
Area: Cariboo - north including Quesnel
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Intermittent, strong wind gusts up to 90 km/h will tonight. The strongest wind gusts will begin to ease early Sunday morning. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with visibility occasionally near zero in blowing snow continue this morning in Naujaat. Tucked between high pressure over western Nunavut and low pressure to the east, northerly winds gusting up to 70 km/h are creating near zero visibilities in blowing snow. These conditions are expected to improve by Monday morning. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility.
